citations.narrative:
Facility employees were responsible for the physical harm and /or unnecessary discomfort to a nonhuman primate when
personnel made a mistake during handling and anesthesia. A nonhuman primate experienced a 3 x 5 inch area of skin
damage on the right dorsal back, which resulted in month long repeated debridements and extensive wound care before
the animal was discharged to their home cage. This trauma was attributed to the administration of subcutaneous fluids
which were inappropriately warmed and delivered to the patient without carefully checking the temperature. Handling of all
animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, physical harm
or unnecessary discomfort.
Corrected prior to inspection on 30 July, 2025

On 2/21/25, two macaques, one injured, were found outside of their shared enclosure, but within the indoor housing room.
It was later noted that the lock used to secure the door to the main enclosure malfunctioned. The injured animal had a
severe right rear leg laceration with muscle transection and a severed calcanean tendon with an associated visible fibula
fracture. After a consultation between veterinary staff and the principal investigator, euthanasia was elected rather than
repair due to study end point timelines. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed so
that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair,
and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.
Corrected prior to inspection on 30 July 2025

In two rooms within the EX area containing nonhuman primates, four animals were contained in enclosures that did not
meet the minimum required floor space under the Animal Welfare Act. In one room, 3 individuals exceeded 10 kilograms
(kgs), but were housed in enclosures that only provided 4.3 square feet of space per individual instead of the required 6
sq feet per individual, and were not obese or pregnant. In another room, an individual was over 10 kgs but was only
housed in 4.3 square feet of space. Most of these animals were pair housed, and their pair mate was under 10 kgs and
therefore had sufficient space. Primary enclosures housing nonhuman primates must meet the minimum space
requirements to ensure the welfare of the animals contained within.
Correct by 15 August 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the IACUC and veterinary staff.
Additional Inspectors:
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.38(f)(1)  Critical
   
Miscellaneous. 
Facility employees were responsible for the physical harm and /or unnecessary discomfort to a nonhuman primate when 
personnel made a mistake during handling and anesthesia. A nonhuman primate experienced a 3 x 5 inch area of skin 
damage on the right dorsal back, which resulted in month long repeated debridements and extensive wound care before 
the animal was discharged to their home cage. This trauma was attributed to the administration of subcutaneous fluids 
which were inappropriately warmed and delivered to the patient without carefully checking the temperature. Handling of all 
animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma, physical harm 
or unnecessary discomfort. 
 
Corrected prior to inspection on 30 July, 2025 
3.80(a)(2)(iii)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
On 2/21/25, two macaques, one injured, were found outside of their shared enclosure, but within the indoor housing room. 
It was later noted that the lock used to secure the door to the main enclosure malfunctioned. The injured animal had a 
severe right rear leg laceration with muscle transection and a severed calcanean tendon with an associated visible fibula 
fracture. After a consultation between veterinary staff and the principal investigator, euthanasia was elected rather than 
repair due to study end point timelines. Housing facilities for nonhuman primates must be designed and constructed so 
that they are structurally sound for the species of nonhuman primates housed in them. They must be kept in good repair, 
and they must protect the animals from injury, contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering. 
 
Corrected prior to inspection on 30 July 2025 
3.80(b)(1) 
   
Primary enclosures. 
In two rooms within the EX area containing nonhuman primates, four animals were contained in enclosures that did not 
meet the minimum required floor space under the Animal Welfare Act. In one room, 3 individuals exceeded 10 kilograms 
(kgs), but were housed in enclosures that only provided 4.3 square feet of space per individual instead of the required 6

sq feet per individual, and were not obese or pregnant. In another room, an individual was over 10 kgs but was only 
housed in 4.3 square feet of space. Most of these animals were pair housed, and their pair mate was under 10 kgs and 
therefore had sufficient space. Primary enclosures housing nonhuman primates must meet the minimum space 
requirements to ensure the welfare of the animals contained within. 
 
Correct by 15 August 2025 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the IACUC and veterinary staff. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
William Campbell, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
